results.title: The Way things go
results.brief_description: Inside a warehouse, artists Peter Fischli and David Weiss build an enormous, precarious structure 100 feet long made out of common household items - tea kettles, tires, old shoes, balloons, wooden ramps, etc. Then, with fire, water, gravity, and chemistry, they create a spectacular chain reaction, a self destructing performance of physical interactions, chemical reactions, and precisely-crafted chaos worthy of Rube Goldberg or Alfred Hitchcock.

results.title: It wasn't me
results.creator_credit: Eddie Moses, John Honey, Tasmanian Film Corporation and Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1978 film consists of a short narrative demonstrating the need for observing industrial safety standards on building sites. The film’s cast of characters includes a wealthy contractor, a negligent foreman, a disgruntled safety warden, a foreign labourer and a department inspector, as they attempt to reconstruct what happened to a missing worker following a trench collapse. Each of the characters avoids responsibility in their roles and blames the others for the accident. Presented as a dramatic short with points of comedy (though this is mainly through the slapstick representation of an Italian worker who doesn’t speak English), the film emphasises the importance of all members of the workforce taking responsibility for upholding safe practices on site.

Produced by the Tasmania Film Corporation for the Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Cast: Peter Aanensen, Frank Bansel, Brendan Cassidy, Cul Cullen, Cliff Ellen, Don Glover, Peter Kay, Kevin Lacey, Robert Larkins, Sue Ellen Peers, Robert Ward

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Cyberthon Archives [documentation]
results.brief_description: Cyberthon was a series of TV broadcast events initiated in the 1990’s in Melbourne, Australia. This collection contains photographs, images and documentation that accompany the moving content in the archive.
results.description: Cyberthon was a series of TV broadcast events initiated in the 1990’s in Melbourne, Australia. This collection contains photographs, images and documentation that accompany the moving content in the archive.

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 03
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Kip and David”.
On the last day of his holiday at Stradbroke Island, David wakes early, feeds the wild horses, then goes for a swim with Kip, the bushland elf. Later they build a sand castle together and slide down the sand dunes before David smuggles Kip in his bag for a holiday in Brisbane. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.

results.title: Kip and David. Episode 04
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Kip and David”.
David and his elfin friend Kip discover many surprises while playing in the garden. A green tree frog hidden in a plant, a shady Traveller’s palm and newly grown mushrooms - ideal stools for Kip. As they search for a dry, sheltered home for Kip, they see bearded dragon and frilled lizards. After clearing a site at the foot of a tree, they draw a plan and prepare to build it. Music by Nancy Tow. Narrated by Roy Dunlop.

results.title: Explosives: the two metre lifeline
results.creator_credit: Donald Crombie, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
In this 1974 film, the use of comedy and narrative drama are employed to demonstrate the correct handling of explosives and detonators. Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Mines Department, the film shows three people who handle explosives in the course of an ordinary day: a farmer removing tree stumps from his paddock, an opal miner in Coober Pedy and a ‘powder monkey’ on a road construction crew.

Introduced by a stereotypical ‘Aussie bloke’ drinking a beer at the pub, the film follows the three protagonists through their separate stories, as the narrator points out the mistakes and correct methods in their techniques. Demonstrating a casual, light-hearted approach to safety instruction, this film is a humorous presentation filled with expletives and colloquial terms, aimed to speak to workers on their level.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Natural Glass
results.creator_credit: John King, Derek Wright and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Looks at a one-man revival of “natural” glass-making in New Zealand, contrasting the delicacies of glass making by one man with his normal job as a worker in a natural gas field.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John King, Derek Wright and New Zealand National Film Unit

results.title: Forgotten people
results.creator_credit: Barry Merton and Mathias, Kenyon and Merton Pictures
results.brief_description:
Shows the work of the Aborigines Advancement League particularly of Pastor Doug Nicholls and Bill Onus. They visit the settlements of Rumbaland, Robinvale and Dareton, showing the primitive conditions in which the aborigines are forced to live. Government housing is not provided at a sufficient rate. This film stresses the need for more positive action.
Sponsored by the Aborigines Advancement League (Victoria) in the wake of the 1967 Referendum, and featuring two of the League’s founding members in Nicholls and Onus.

results.title: Exploration 1770, reviewed 1970
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Stanley Dalby and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Contrasts Captain Cook’s observations on his voyage along the eastern coast of Australia in 1770 with scenes of the Royal Visit in 1970 and bicentenary celebrations including re-enactments of his landings. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Bagnall, Stanley Dalby and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Magic Lantern Set Effects Slide [Farmer and Pig]
results.brief_description: Hand painted magic lantern slipping slide in wooden frame. [Farmer and Pig] shows a farmer with a cane and a pig, when the slipping slide is moved, the farmer hits the pig with the cane and it jumps upwards.
